job_title: Senior Support Worker in Bristol, England
pros: If you want to work 24/7 all hours round the clock with no sleep and in an unsafe enviroment then this company will be great for you.
cons:
- Don't care about staff or client safety
- Accept clients that staff have no training to be able to support them appropriately. For example with psychosis and other mental health disorders. Staff have no training on this and expected to to know how to support and handle psychotic episodes lone working. 
- You are expected to work 60hrs+ weekly and all around the clock. 
- Expected to work 24hr shifts with no sleep. 
- Management are unsupportive and don't care. 
- Go against multiple legislations, for example expecting staff to hold and administer medication. 
- When lone working and serious incidents happen on call management don't answer the phone and are not there to support you.
- Expected to lone work with up to 20 clients at a time and their friends who also come on site. 
- Staff expected to give everything but when you need support from your workplace there is nothing. When I had covid they refused me SSP even though I was employed as full time. I was expected to work 24hrs waking shifts and 60hr weeks. They drain you and take everything from you but will give nothing back. 

I could go on with plenty more, it is poorly organised and the company priorities expending the business rather than ensuring a high quality workplace and supported living environment for clients. They care more about the money then the support needs for the clients and the staffing safety.

job_title: Senior Support Worker in Worcester, England
pros: I started to work for the CCP about nine months ago as a housing support worker and have been promoted to senior when I finished my probation period after I passed the interview. Seniors, managers and support workers are always there to guide and to support you. I never felt this valued in my work life and I love the job we do. It is true that our job can be challenging but it is also very rewarding. Helping people to stop being homeless and fulfil their dreams and aspirations is the best of my role and I wouldn't change what I am doing for the world.

job_title: Recruitment and Development Manager in Cheltenham, England
pros:
Great culture and determination to continually improve things, for staff and clients.

Open door senior management, who listen to feedback and act on it.

The charity makes a big impact across a number of counties.

The job role I have is varied and interesting and although stressful at times, it is very rewarding.

I would highly recommend as there is also lots of career progression.

Good benefits compared to similar organisations including 25 days holiday, enhanced pension and sickness pay as well as life insurance and much more.
cons: Some processes can be convoluted, however CCP are investing in new systems which has already helped.

job_title: Housing Services Manager in Cheltenham, England

cons: The starting salaries are not great as we are a charity - but staff who work hard are recognised and given the chance to move up the ladder, improving their salary as well as gaining valuable experience.
